column4: I had netbeans installed on 8.10, and apparently the upgrade to 9.04 removed the package but left orphaned files (like the binary) still on my system. What's the easiest way to scrub my system of these unwanted, non-working files?
we have a new tool under administration, system janitor
the *old* way would be to see if apt-get autoremove would take care of them
gartal: Neither took care of it :/

I'm not sure where all the files are. It's still in my Applications menu, and apparently that points to /user/local/netbeans-6.5/bin/netbeans but I'm not sure where else files might live and how to remove it from my apps menu
try sudo appt-get autoremove, if you didnt make the assumption earlier
Yeah, that's what I meant when I said I tried both, it didn't work either. Right now I'm trying a 'find / -name netbeans 2> /dev/null' but I dunno how to remove it from my menu
stupid question on my part, but, have you tryed sudo apt-get purge netbeans?
Package netbeans is not installed. Looks to have done nothing.
hit up, and try auto-completiing the packaage name..
apt-cache search shows the only netbeans package is "netbeans"
search forums, im at a los, i never use netbeans
Lol I'm wishing I had never tried it now - I moved on to eclipse. Thanks for trying.
